G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The combination of Defendant’s relocation to another state, the practical effect on the minor child’s school schedule and extracurricular activities, and the child’s increasing age and associated school and social demands is a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of the prior order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable case law, including Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010), and Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 112 (2012).

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.proposition: Frequent, lengthy, and burdensome travel time associated with a parenting plan, especially on school nights, is a factor courts may consider in determining whether an existing plan remains in the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion focuses on statutory interpretation under the paternity statute and the impermissibility of ordering the mother to relocate back to Massachusetts after a lawful move, not on the substantive best‑interests analysis of a parenting plan. Travel distance (400 miles) is mentioned only as context and as something relevant to crafting a long-distance visitation order, not as a factor in determining whether an existing parenting plan remains in the child’s best interests. The opinion does not discuss frequent, lengthy, or burdensome travel time for the child, particularly on school nights, as a best‑interests factor.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … [T]he distance separating the parties had relevance only as a factor in devising a reasonable long-distance visitation order….”

Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 M.raw_text: Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 112 (2012)
Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 M.proposition: The combination of Defendant’s relocation to another state, the practical effect on the minor child’s school schedule and extracurricular activities, and the child’s increasing age and associated school and social demands is a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of the prior order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable case law, including Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010), and Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 112 (2012).
Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 M.support_reasoning: This opinion is a divorce, valuation, alimony, and contempt case; it does not involve a complaint to modify a custody or parenting-time order, nor does it discuss G.L. c. 208, § 28, relocation, school or extracurricular schedules, or a child’s increasing age and social demands as a basis for modification. Its only reference to modification is a single sentence noting that the husband might seek modification of alimony/child support if the wife’s business income changes. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about a material and substantial change in custody/parenting circumstances.
Subsequent to Custody of Sorentino, 81 M.relevant_excerpt: “The judge noted that ‘the wife’s 24.75 [percent] interests in each of the family businesses … may eventually generate income to [the] Wife to a greater degree than they presently do, and the Husband may, in the event that a material change in circumstances occurs, seek a modification of the current alimony and or child support orders.’”}

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a probate and family court may modify a prior custody and parenting judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.

Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190 (1952).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a probate and family court may modify a prior custody and parenting judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.
Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190 (1952).support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G. L. c. 208, § 28 and states that a change in an order for custody or maintenance must ordinarily be based on a change in circumstances since the prior decree, and then affirms a modification based on such changed circumstances, expressly tied to the children’s welfare. The court’s reasoning and application focus on both the existence of material changes and the best interests/benefit of the children, squarely supporting the proposition about when modification is proper under Massachusetts law.
Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190 (1952).relevant_excerpt: “It must now be considered as settled that, ordinarily at least, a change in an order for custody or maintenance under G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 208, § 28, must be based upon some change in the circumstances of the parties since the preceding decree was entered… But in the present case… we think it appears that there were material changes in circumstances… and that the last decree rests upon these circumstances… [and] that custody in the father had not proved successful, and that the children would be better off if returned to their mother…”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a probate and family court may modify a prior custody and parenting judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is in the best interests of the child.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The case deals with modification of alimony and child support, not with modification of custody or parenting time. The court articulates the standard for modifying support orders (material change in circumstances and consideration of needs/ability to pay), but it does not address custody or parenting judgments or explicitly apply a best-interests-of-the-child standard in that context. Therefore it is not proper authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody and parenting judgments.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28 ….”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: The best interests of the child standard governs all custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion strongly affirms that the best interests of the child standard governs custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and more generally that it is the traditional touchstone for custody and visitation in Massachusetts. However, it does not state that this standard governs *all* custody and parenting time determinations in every statutory context (e.g., modifications, removal, DCF care and protection). Thus it supports a broad, central role for the best interests test, but not the universal "all custody and parenting time determinations" formulation in the proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … This case raises the question of the relationship between the ‘best interests of the child’ standard set forth in the first paragraph of the statute and the three requirements set forth in the second. … The required considerations … neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The best interests of the child standard governs all custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses and applies the best interests of the child framework implicitly (including reference to statutory requirements in G.L. c. 208, § 31) and emphasizes factors that must be considered, such as domestic violence. However, it does not state or hold that the best interests of the child standard governs all custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts in a general, across-the-board way. The case is focused on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence in a particular custody dispute, not on articulating a universal rule about all custody and parenting time matters.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. ... [Domestic violence] must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody."

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 192\.proposition: In assessing best interests, Massachusetts courts consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, the stability and continuity of the child’s environment, the child’s educational and social needs, and each parent’s ability to meet those needs.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 192\.support_reasoning: The opinion does briefly reference the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in the context of a custody modification, but it does not list or discuss specific best-interest factors such as age, developmental needs, stability and continuity of environment, or educational and social needs. Instead, it holds that the judge must make specific findings and consider ‘all relevant factors’ without identifying what those factors are. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the detailed, factor-based proposition stated.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 192\.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’”

Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602\u.proposition: In assessing best interests, Massachusetts courts consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, the stability and continuity of the child’s environment, the child’s educational and social needs, and each parent’s ability to meet those needs.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602\u.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness and the propriety of giving substantial weight to the wishes of a mature child in a care and protection context. It does not set out or discuss a multi-factor “best interests” test that includes the child’s age and developmental needs, stability and continuity of environment, educational and social needs, and each parent’s ability to meet those needs. Any references to the child’s psychological condition or school progress are case-specific facts, not an articulated general standard, so the case does not provide authority for the broad proposition stated.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602\u.relevant_excerpt: “The judge summarized the psychologist’s testimony as follows: ‘He found that Dom had closed a three year gap in his academic learning and was now almost at Grade level. He has definitely attached himself to the DeWitts and sees them as his psychological parents who will care for him. Dom still has severe psychological differences with his natural mother who he feels does not love him and will not care for him and to take Dom out of the DeWitt family would be psychologically devastating and deleterious to his emotional growth as an adolescent because of the attachments he has made with them.’”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–739 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions make clear that a prior custody or parenting judgment, even if originally appropriate, must be revisited when circumstances change so that continued enforcement would no longer serve the child’s welfare.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly applies G.L. c. 208, § 28’s ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard to a post‑divorce custody modification request, and affirms that prior custody arrangements may be modified when circumstances change and a different arrangement is necessary for the children’s best interests. The court upholds the finding of a material change (the mother’s rehabilitation since the prior judgment) and remands for a new custody determination guided by the children’s welfare, which fits the proposition that earlier custody judgments must be revisited when changed circumstances mean continued enforcement would not serve the child’s welfare.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’… the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: In addition, although this Complaint for Modification does not seek or oppose removal of the child from Massachusetts within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 30, the relocation context is analogous in that the Court must weigh the practical effect of geography and travel on the child’s life.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas is a classic removal/relocation case directly applying G.L. c. 208, § 30. The quoted pages set out the standards governing when a custodial parent may remove a child from the Commonwealth and discuss the impact of relocation on visitation and the child’s interests. The proposition claims the complaint ‘does not seek or oppose removal … within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 30’ and invokes relocation only by analogy; Yannas, however, is not an analogy but the primary authority interpreting that very statute, so it does not support the premise that the matter is outside § 30 and merely analogous to relocation.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: In addition, although this Complaint for Modification does not seek or oppose removal of the child from Massachusetts within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 30, the relocation context is analogous in that the Court must weigh the practical effect of geography and travel on the child’s life.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: The case is a classic removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a non‑removal modification case. However, in explaining how to decide removal disputes in a joint physical custody context, the court explicitly states that the judge must consider the practical impact of distance, including increased travel time between households and schools and other burdens of geography, on the child’s best interests. That reasoning is analogous to the proposition’s point that, even outside strict § 30 removal, a court should weigh the practical effects of geography and travel on the child’s life.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Joint physical custody need not necessarily be impeded by relocation outside the Commonwealth. In some cases, distance between the parents may not greatly increase as a result of removal… It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 30.proposition: In addition, although this Complaint for Modification does not seek or oppose removal of the child from Massachusetts within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 30, the relocation context is analogous in that the Court must weigh the practical effect of geography and travel on the child’s life.

Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325,.raw_text: Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325, 332–333 (2010)
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that where a schedule interferes with a child’s education, stability, or well‑being, the schedule must yield to the child’s best interests.
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard and contrasts it with the Lebanese Jaafarite Court’s presumptive, gender‑based custody rules. However, it does not address or decide any issue about parenting-time or visitation schedules interfering with a child’s education, stability, or well‑being, nor does it state that a particular schedule must yield when it conflicts with those interests. The case is about comity and substantial conformity of foreign custody law, not schedule modification based on interference with education or stability.
Charara v. Yatim, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325,.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth… What is in a child’s best interest depends upon the particular needs of the child, and is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who ‘may consider any factor pertinent to those interests.’ … The best interests analysis our courts employ is thus unlike the presumptive entitlement to custody that governed the custody proceeding in the Jaafarite Court in Lebanon.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The requested relief is also consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 31, which requires the Court to “consider the best interests of the child” in determining custody and parenting time and to “presume that frequent and continuing contact with the parents is in the best interests of the child” where appropriate, while recognizing that the form of such contact must not be detrimental to the child.
